newsitem.title: HUNGARY: FIRST HUNGARY FUND MAY FLOAT NABI, BIOREX IN 1997.
newsitem.headline: FIRST HUNGARY FUND MAY FLOAT NABI, BIOREX IN 1997.

text.p: The First Hungary Fund (FHF), a venture capital investor, is looking to float two Hungarian companies in its portfolio, biotech company Biorex and busmaker North American Bus Industries Ltd (NABI), later this year.
"We would float Biorex on the London Stock Exchange (LSE) and NABI on the Budapest bourse and the London OTC market," the fund's chairman and CEO Peter Rona told Reuters.
The FHF was set up in 1989 to invest in unlisted companies, make them more profitable and, where appropriate, bring them to market listing.
Rona said the Biotex flotation depended on human tests currently underway in Britain and Hungary for a new product, Bimoclomol, a treatment for diabetic complications.
"The tests will be completed in June 30," he said. "If they are successsful, as we believe they will be, then we will seek the listing."
The FHF set up a UK company BRX Research and Development Company Ltd last year as a holding company for 100 percent of Biorex shares.
Rona said the decision to issue Biorex shares in London was based on the LSE's Chapter 20 regulation encouraging the listing of hi-tech companies.

"(It demands) some tangible results from your research, stability of management and the existence of an identifiable research programme," he said. "You don't have to be profitable, you don't need an earnings history, and you don't have to have a product on the market -- Biorex fits Chapter 20."

Rona said the decision to float NABI was based on a turnaround in the company's fortunes over the last two years, during which a combined 1994/95 loss of $3 million has been turned into a $3.7 million 1996 after-tax profit.
"The company is growing very fast, it's turning away orders," he said, adding that NASI now accounted for 15 percent of the U.S. bus market and expected 1997 net income of over $5 million.
